Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EarthScope Chronicles: Scientists' Stories and Media-Rich Earth Science Investigations
Award.AbstractNarration: TERC, in collaboration with McLean Media, is developing multimedia-rich teaching modules that highlight the work and personal stories of EarthScope scientists and engage students in grades 7-12 in data-based investigations connected to the scientists? research. The EarthScope Chronicles modules include compelling videos that feature interviews with scientists and footage of them conducting EarthScope research. The investigations incorporate EarthScope visualizations, data, data products, and geospatial technology to connect STEM classroom content to current real-world scientific research. To increase EarthScope?s visibility within the educational community and the public at large, individual media resources from the modules, such as video clips, image sets, and e-books are distributed through online digital libraries and social media sites such as TeacherTube, YouTube, Vimeo, and STEM Stories. EarthScope Chronicles modules raise awareness of EarthScope research initiatives and resulting scientific discoveries, support the use of EarthScope visualizations, data, and data products in middle- and high-school classrooms, and provide engaging multimedia resources and a replicable model for connecting STEM classroom curriculum to current real-world research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), EarthScope is a network of observatories acting as an Earth "telescope" focused on both the exterior and interior structure and dynamics of our planet. It uses global positioning system (GPS) stations, strainmeters, and hundreds of both stationary and transportable seismometers located across the continental United States.

The NSF-funded EarthScope Chronicles project is a collaborative effort between TERC and McLean Media to develop multimedia-rich teaching modules that highlight the work and personal stories of EarthScope scientists and engage students in grades 7-12 in data-based investigations connected to the scientists’ research. This project was designed to meet the following goals:

  • Raise awareness of EarthScope research initiatives and resulting scientific discoveries
  • Support the use of EarthScope visualizations, data, and data products in middle- and high-school classrooms
  • Develop engaging multimedia resources and a replicable model for connecting STEM classroom curriculum to current real-world research

The EarthScope Chronicles model uses video vignettes and data-based investigations to increase (1) access to quality materials; (2) personal connections among students and scientists; (3) visibility of women and minorities as role models; and (4) interactive experiences that underrepresented students might not otherwise have.

 McLean Media’s main contribution to the project has been to produce 25 short videos featuring interviews with scientists and footage of them conducting EarthScope research. Video production took place at multiple locations, including Idaho, Wisconsin, Oregon, Vermont, California, and Texas.

These videos are being incorporated into online data-based investigations produced by TERC that include EarthScope visualizations, data, data products, and geospatial technology to connect STEM classroom content to current, real-world scientific research. A range of evaluation and dissemination activities will also be employed when the TERC modules are complete. The modules will align with Next Generation Science Standards and be disseminated widely online through education portals.

One EarthScope project that features heavily in the video series is the Idaho-Oregon project (IDOR). IDOR combined data from multiple sources, including research on gravity, seismology, structural geology, and geochronology, to study a boundary that occurred on the edge of North America between Idaho and Oregon and understand how it has evolved through geologic time. The Chronicles crew accompanied several IDOR teams in Idaho as they collected gravity readings, took rock samples, and removed a seismometer. Additional EarthScope projects highlighted include the Superior Province Rifting EarthScope Experiment (SPREE), the Plate Boundary Observatory, the San Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth (SAFOD), and the Rio Grande Rift project. In addition, several individuals who use EarthScope data were introduced in the series, including Harmony Colella, who investigates slow-slip earthquakes, Emily Hooft, whose research focuses on studying volcanoes, and Jenny Nakai, who is building an earthquake catalog for the Rio Grande region.
